I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During  the  2005  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) (the Government) confirmed its request for technical assistance (TA) 
from the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help the State Administration of Work Safety 
(SAWS) develop its strategy for improving coal mine safety. The TA is included in the country 
program for 2006.1 In February 2006, a Fact-Finding Mission was fielded to prepare the TA 
report and hold discussions with representatives from the Government, SAWS, and the Zheng 
Mei Group Company (ZMG), a key state-owned coal mine company, responsible for most  
mining  activities  in  the  Zhengzhou  coal  mine  area.  Agreement  was  reached  with  the 
Government regarding the TA’s impact, outcome, outputs, implementation arrangements, costs, 
and  financing  arrangements  and  the  consultants’  terms  of  reference.  The  TA  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Between 1990 and 2003, the total death toll from mine accidents in the PRC was 91,459 
people, or an average annual death toll of 6,532 people. In 2003, the world’s coal output was 
about 5 billion tons and the death toll from mine accidents was around 8,000 people, yet while 
the PRC produced only 35% of the world’s coal output, it accounted for 80% of the world’s 
death toll from mine accidents. Also in 2003, average coal production per person-year was 321 
tons in the PRC, 2.2% of the productivity in the United States and 8.1% of the productivity in 
South Africa, but the death rate per ton of coal produced was 100 times that in the United States 
and 30 times that in South Africa. Between December 2004 and February 2005, three major 
coal mine accidents resulted in more than 100 deaths per event. In 2005, in an effort to reduce 
the number of coal mine accidents the State Council established a ministry-level task force. 
 
3.  The PRC is the world’s largest coal producer and consumer. The recent large increase 
in the country’s demand for energy has resulted in rapid growth of coal consumption. The output 
of raw coal increased from 990 million tons in 2000 to 2.1 billion tons in 2004. With production in 
many coal mines at 1.5 to 2.0 times higher than the mines’ design capacities, and given the lack 
of safety measures and regulations, particularly for the large number of small coal mines, 
accidents occur frequently, leading to severe social and economic consequences. The safety 
situation in coal mines, particularly in small mines with poor mine safety facilities, is deteriorating 
and the number of accidents is increasing. Each year, small mines, which tend to employ poor 
people from rural areas, continue to account for 70% of all coal mine incidents. In response, the 
Government is increasing its efforts to improve coal mine safety. In 2005, the State Council 
issued the Special Stipulations of the State Council on Prevention and Control of Coal Mine 
Accidents, which propose measures2 for preventing and controlling coal mine accidents and 
focus on strengthening the technical and institutional capacity of coal mines. 
 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 16 June 2006. 
2  These include (i) imposing penalties on coal mines with hidden operational risks;  (ii) identifying situations under 
which coal mines have to be closed and risks to safety addressed; (iii) mandating the need for detailed measures 
and systems, including proper education and training for preventing major mine accidents; (iv) assigning main 
responsibility for accidents to executives of coal mine enterprises as appropriate and imposing sanctions; and (v) 
assigning responsibility for accidents to local government units as appropriate and imposing sanctions. In addition, 
the  following  measures  for  controlling  explosive  gases  were  also  proposed:  (i)  enhancing  research  and 
development in relation to measures for controlling gas, (ii) promoting the comprehensive development and use of 
coal bed methane, (iii) sending supervision teams to 45 key coal enterprises, (iv) organizing experts to undertake 
diagnoses operations in coal mines with serious gas problems, (v) carrying out appropriate measures to prevent 
production at levels that exceed capacity, (vi) performing technical upgrading for coal mines with dynamic gas 
phenomena, and (vii) popularizing the remote system for digital gas monitoring and control.

2   
4.  Investigations  of  various  coal  mine  accidents  in  the  PRC  have  shown  that  gas 
explosions and roof collapses account for more than 70% of all mine accidents and 74% of total 
fatalities. Serious accidents that resulted in more than 30 deaths were mostly due to gas 
explosions. Methane3 is a serious hazard in coal mines because of its highly explosive nature. It 
must be removed during, and sometimes prior to, actual coal mining operations to ensure 
workers’ safety. Even though the drainage of methane has been practiced for decades, current 
practices do not always meet national standards, hence the numerous fatal explosions. Roof 
collapses are often caused by water inundation from aquifers and from water bodies created 
during dewatering operations. Water management without appropriate training and lacking a 
proper understanding of geological conditions presents a serious threat to miners’ safety. 
 
5.  In 2003, 4,143 mine accidents killed 6,434 people. Of these, 531 accidents that killed 
892 people occurred in key state-owned mines4, accounting for 14% of all the deaths; 607 
accidents that killed 881 people happened in local state-owned mines, accounting for 14% of 
deaths; and 3,005 accidents killing 4,661 people took place in mines owned by small towns and 
villages, accounting for 72% of deaths. The high death toll in the latter is particular cause for 
concern. 
 
6.  The Zhengzhou mining area in Henan province has been selected for a pilot study to 
develop  a  comprehensive  approach  addressing  coal  mine  safety.  It  will  serve  as  a 
demonstration site that can be replicated throughout the PRC. The Zhengzhou coal mine area is 
a  typical  PRC  coal  mine  area  in  terms  of  its  safety  conditions  and  problems  and  mining 
development history. ZMG, a key state-owned coal mine company, is responsible for the major 
mining activities in the Zhengzhou coal mine area, together with a large number of village and 
township coal mines administered by the Coal Administration Bureau of Zhengzhou Municipality 
(CABZM). In 2000, the Zhengzhou coal mine area had more than 900 small mines. This number 
was reduced to 513 mines in 2004. The raw coal output of the Zhengzhou mining area was 41 
million tons in 2004, using more than 250,000 workers. On 20 October 2004, a gas explosion 
accident occurred in ZMG’s Daping Mine that killed 148 workers. 
 
7.  By  addressing  safety  issues,  particularly  in  small  coal  mines,  the  TA  will  have  a 
significant impact on poverty reduction. Estimates indicate that more than 80% of coal miners 
are poor and uneducated. For example, fewer than 2% of workers in the Zhengzhou coal mines 
have completed high school or have higher qualifications. Also, most miners work as temporary 
day workers and therefore lack job security. Because of their poor safety records and low 
mining efficiency, the Government plans to close most small coal mines, which will have a 
significant impact on workers’ welfare. Local governments are extremely concerned about the 
reemployment of workers who will be displaced by the closure of small coal mines. Thus, 
measures need to be taken to provide training for these workers to improve the safety record of 
small coal mines and/or to prepare them for employment in large, modern coal mines or in other 
employment alternatives.5 Both ZMG and CABZM have supported measures to improve coal 
mine safety and poverty reduction. 
                                                 
3  Methane gas forms at the same time coal forms and is absorbed in the coal seam. The gas is released as a result 
of temperature and pressure changes when underground coal is mined or exposed to surface conditions. Methane 
released through wells drilled from the surface into underground coal seams is referred to as coal bed methane, 
while coal mine methane refers to methane released through mine shafts during underground coal mining 
operations. 
4  Coal mines in China are classified into (i) key state-owned mines (large, generally modern, and are under the 
provincial government control); (ii) local state-owned mines (smaller, partially mechanized, administered by the 
provincial governments); and (iii) town and village mines (small and use manual mining techniques, run by local 
governments and private individuals). 
5  ADB is also funding ADTA-4680-PRC (ADB. 2005. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for 
Alternative Livelihood Options to Facilitate Coal Sector Reforms. Manila) to address this concern.

3
 
8.  By reducing gas explosions, the TA will also have substantial environmental benefits. 
Coal mines in the PRC have high coal bed methane (CBM) and coal mine methane (CMM) 
content. Most of the methane removed during mining operations is not used as an energy 
source, but is emitted into the environment as a greenhouse gas. Coal mines in the PRC 
released approximately 6 billion cubic meters of methane into the atmosphere in 2003 and are 
expected to release approximately 10 billion cubic meters per year by 2010. As a greenhouse 
gas, methane is approximately 21 times more potent than carbon dioxide. Henan province is 
one of the major coal-producing areas in the PRC and produces high methane emissions 
because of its geological conditions. The TA will assess how methane can be commercially 
extracted and used as an economic source of energy that will be distributed to households and 
industries.  Efficient  extraction  and  utilization  of  methane  will  help  reduce  greenhouse  gas 
emissions, improve the safety of coal mines, and reduce domestic use of coal. 
 
9.  The  Government’s  development  objectives  include  containing  the  worsening 
environmental pollution and improving coal mine safety to demonstrate that rapid economic 
growth and a cleaner environment are compatible. SAWS will strengthen its control over coal 
mine safety by issuing regulations. Monitoring and enforcement will also be improved. ADB’s 
operational strategy in the PRC aims at helping the country achieve economic growth in an 
efficient, equitable, and sustainable manner. ADB’s energy sector strategy in the PRC includes 
developing cleaner energy sources, renovating and retrofitting existing facilities to improve 
efficiency and reduce emissions, promoting the corporatization and commercialization of energy 
utilities, and introducing pricing and tariff reforms. This is complemented by ADB’s strategy for 
the environment sector, which supports the use of economic, supply-side, and other measures 
to ensure the sustainable utilization of natural resources; promotes market-based pricing; and 
encourages cost recovery and better disclosure of information about environmental issues. The 
Government has a plan to improve coal mine safety by 2008 and the TA is a major part of this 
effort. With joint efforts by SAWS and ADB, ZMG and CABZM will seek approval from the 
Government to develop a project that will promote coal mine safety. By carefully developing a 
coal mine safety strategy and encouraging active policy dialogue, the TA is consistent with and 
provides  support  for  SAWS’s  objectives  and  is  also  consistent  with  ADB’s  energy  sector 
strategy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
10.  The  impact  of  the  TA  will  be  an  improvement  in  the  safety  and  environmental 
sustainability of coal mining in the PRC. Its outcome will be the adoption and implementation of 
a strategy for enhancing safety in coal mines. The strategy will consider how to (i) enhance the 
prevention  and  control  of  accidents,  (ii)  strengthen  safety  management  in coal  mines  and 
promote policy reforms, and (iii) reduce the release of methane gas into the environment. The 
TA  will  help  meet  the  Government’s  target  of  addressing  safety  problems  in  coal  mines, 
particularly small coal mines, by 2008. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
11.  The outputs of the TA will be:  
(i)  a coal mine safety strategy that will include a proposal for restructuring coal mines, 
particularly small coal mines, to improve coal mine safety by means of various reform 
measures; and

4   
(ii) a coal mine safety action plan up to 2020 for the Zhengzhou mining area that will 
include (a) an assessment of the technologies for accident prevention and control, 
particularly  drainage  technologies,  and  for  improving  CBM  and  CMM  utilization, 
monitoring, and control; (b) a strategy for public dissemination of the TA’s findings 
and  recommendations,  including  comprehensive  training  courses;  and  (c)  the 
identification and prioritization of candidate coal mine safety projects for possible 
ADB financing, and based on the recommendation, an evaluation of the pilot project.  
 
12.  The TA will be implemented in close consultation with all stakeholders and interested 
parties, including targeted miners and potential private sector investors. The TA will be carried 
out in three parts. In part I, the consultants will undertake a detailed background study to gain a 
thorough understanding of the issues related to coal mine safety that will include data gathering 
and preliminary analysis. During part II, the consultants will conduct an international seminar to 
identify the main issues to be addressed to achieve the TA’s objectives, reform measures 
required to address these issues, and suitable international best practices. Under part III, the 
consultants will analyze in detail the issues relating to coal mine safety and assess the selected 
coal  mine  safety  pilot  project.  The  consultants  will  make  assessments  from  technical, 
institutional,  social  and  poverty  impact,  economic,  pricing,  financial,  and  environmental 
viewpoints. The consultants’ recommendations will be discussed at a workshop with the main 
stakeholders. The consultants will organize a final workshop with the main stakeholders to 
disseminate the TA’s findings and recommendations.  
 
13.  The international seminar will introduce and evaluate international experience in related 
areas and its relevance in the PRC context, to be incorporated into the coal mine safety 
strategy. International and national experts will be invited to present papers and participate in 
the  discussions.  After  the  seminar,  the  consultants  will  prepare  a  report  summarizing  the 
discussions and identifying issues relevant to the PRC context. The TA includes a 2-week 
program of international field study to expose selected PRC personnel to the latest trends and 
international best practices in coal mine safety. Participants will include personnel from SAWS, 
ZMG, and other government agencies involved in policymaking and in the implementation of 
coal mine safety. The consultants will consider the particular needs of study participants and 
prepare a study proposal for ADB approval that specifies the (i) objectives of the field study 
program, (ii) institutions to be visited, (iii) agenda for discussions and training, (iv) name and job 
description of each person nominated to participate in the field study, and (v) costs. Selection 
procedures for the international field study program will have to be acceptable to ADB and take 
economy and efficiency considerations into account. At the end of the field study program, the 
participants will submit a group report to ADB summarizing the findings and observations, 
including an initial assessment of which practices and technologies could be applicable to PRC.  
 
14.  The major assumptions in relation to the successful implementation of the TA include 
continued emphasis on improving the safety of coal mining; adequate counterpart support; 
adequate  and  timely  provision  of  data  and  submission  of  required  studies;  and  active 
participation by stakeholders in workshops, seminars, surveys, and/or field visits and in the pilot 
project.  In addition,  the  Government’s continuing  commitment  to  coal  sector  reforms,  tariff 
reforms and rationalization, and transparent regulation is necessary for the success of the TA. 
There is a risk that the demand for coal will continue unabated and that small coal mines will 
have large incentives to increase production, even if mining conditions are unsafe. Efforts will be 
made to ensure that competent consultants will be recruited in time. SAWS is committed to 
necessary  reforms  and  has  agreed  to  provide  adequate  counterpart  support  and  data  as 
needed.  Close  coordination  will  be  maintained  among  the  consultants,  executing  and 
implementing agencies, and ADB.

5
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $850,000 equivalent. The Government has requested ADB 
to finance $600,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA funding 
program. The Government will finance the balance of the TA costs, equivalent to $250,000 
(29%) through the provision of in-kind contributions (in the form of office space and facilities and 
salaries for counterpart staff) and funding of part of the cost for the 2-week field study program. 
The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  SAWS will be the executing agency for the TA and ZMG will be the implementing 
agency. ADB will engage international and national consultants, in consultation with SAWS, 
according to its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants by Asian Development Bank and its 
Borrowers. A full technical proposal will be requested by ADB and consultants will be recruited 
using the quality- and cost-based selection method. An estimated total of 55 person-months of 
consulting services will be required: 10 person-months for international consultants and 45 
person-months for national consultants. The international consultants will have expertise in (i) 
coal mine safety, (ii) institutional analysis, (iii) economic analysis and analysis of coal prices and 
other  tariff  regulations  and  reforms,  (iv)  financial  analysis,  (v)  poverty  impact  and  social 
assessment, and (vii) environmental assessment. The national consultants will have the same 
expertise. The outline terms of reference for consultants are given in Appendix 3. 
 
17.  SAWS will establish a counterpart team with representatives from SAWS and ZMG. The 
counterpart team will interact closely with the consultants during implementation of the TA. 
SAWS  will  also  establish  a  steering  committee  comprising  senior  SAWS  officials  and 
representatives from other government organizations and agencies involved in formulating and 
implementing coal mine safety. The steering committee will be the apex body that will convey 
and  interpret  the  Government’s  views  on  policy  issues  and  generally  oversee  TA 
implementation. The counterpart team members will interact with members of the steering 
committee to seek clarification of issues and matters that fall outside the purview of SAWS. 
SAWS will provide interpreters, local transportation, and office space equipped with suitable 
office facilities in Beijing. ZMG will provide interpreters, local transportation, and office space 
equipped with suitable office facilities in the city of Zhengzhou. Some of the office equipment will 
be financed under the TA and will be procured by the international consultants in accordance 
with  ADB’s  Procurement  Guidelines.  This  equipment  will  be  handed  over  to  SAWS  upon 
completion of the TA. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 9 months beginning on 1 December 2006, with an 
expected completion date of 30 August 2007. Information on the progress of implementation 
and  on  TA  outputs  will  be  disseminated  through  the  TA  information  dissemination  and 
awareness program, including the special web site that is to be developed. The outcome of the 
TA will be subject to evaluation by both ADB and the Government in accordance with their 
respective evaluation policies and requirements.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $600,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of the People’s Republic of China for the Coal Mine Safety Study, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

Appendix 3  9 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be carried out by a consulting firm with experience in 
the areas of expertise required. The study will require about 10 person-months of international 
consultants and 45 person-months of national consulting services. The team of international 
consultants will consist of a coal mine safety engineer, an institutional specialist, a social and 
poverty impact specialist, an energy economist and coal price specialist, a financial analyst, an 
environmental  specialist,  and  a  coal  mine  safety  training  specialist.  To  ensure  effective 
assistance to the international consultants, the team of national consultants will have the same 
team composition. The consultants will work in close collaboration with the State Administration 
of Work Safety (SAWS) as the executing agency and will ensure the effective transfer of know-
how. The Zheng Mei Group Company (ZMG) will be the implementing agency for the pilot 
project.  The  international  consultants  will  be  recruited  in  accordance  with  the  Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB’s) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. 
 
2.  On commencement of the TA, the consultants will undertake a detailed background 
study to gain a thorough understanding of the issues related to coal mine safety in the People’s 
Republic of China (PRC). The consultants will review relevant reports and studies, including 
those of SAWS and of international agencies, including ADB, the World Bank, and others. The 
consultants will have discussions with members of the steering committee and with counterpart 
team members to obtain a good understanding of the Government’s reform directions and to 
establish  a  sound  basis  for  the  TA  work.  The  consultants  should  evaluate  international 
experience  in  related  areas  and  its  relevance  in  the  PRC  context  and  should  tailor  their 
recommendations to reflect the situation in the PRC to ensure that they are relevant and can be 
implemented effectively. The presentation of recommendations should focus on how to proceed 
from the current stage of coal mine safety.   
 
A.  Part I: Preliminary Analysis 
 
3.  During part I, the consultants will do the following: 
(i)  Trace the history of coal mine safety regulations in the PRC and present a clear 
picture of mine safety in the PRC, including (a) current mine safety monitoring 
technologies,  safety  check  procedures,  emergency  plans,  and  training  and 
education programs used by various large and small coal mines; (b) current mine 
safety  policies  and  regulations  and  monitoring  enforcement  procedures  by 
central  and  provincial  governments;  (c)  roles  of,  responsibilities  of,  and 
relationship among entities within these government bodies and other relevant 
institutions;  and  (d)  effectiveness  of  the  current  government  policies  and 
regulations and monitoring and enforcement procedures. 
(ii)  Organize  and  conduct  a  survey  of  identified  stakeholders  in  the  Zhengzhou 
mining area. The survey will provide a basis for impact assessment of the TA. 
(iii)   Evaluate in detail mine accidents related to safety issues in the PRC, including 
(a) classification of the types of accidents; (b) frequencies of occurrence and 
number of fatalities for each type of accident, particularly those related to mine 
explosions  and  flooding;  and  (c)  main  causes  of  the  accidents  and  any 
subsequent corrective measures taken. 
(iv)  Assess the level of spending by mining companies on promoting and ensuring 
mine safety requirements as required by the central and provincial governments, 
or on a voluntary basis. 
(v)  Identify barriers other than budgetary barriers for enhancing mine safety in the 
PRC. 
(vi)  Describe any new mine safety initiatives proposed or considered by the central 
and provincial governments, including the plans and programs for achieving the 
initiatives’  objectives.  Determine  if  these  reform  measures  and  plans  are 
adequate to remove the barriers.

10  Appendix 3   
 
(vii)  Review current assistance to the PRC by ADB and other donor and funding 
agencies for extracting coal bed methane (CBM) or coal mine methane (CMM) 
and link the benefits of these methane extraction projects to mitigation of the 
potential for explosions and for generating additional revenues to finance mine 
safety improvements. 
(viii)  Review other types of assistance being provided by other donor and funding 
agencies for enhancing coal mine safety in the PRC and discuss any potential 
joint efforts with ADB with these agencies to further promote and implement coal 
mine safety. 
(ix)  Review the current coal pricing structure in the PRC and potential impacts on 
pricing resulting from the increased costs associated with enhancing mine safety. 
(x)  Review existing institutional and financing mechanisms in the PRC for coal mine 
companies to invest in mine safety. 
(xi)  Conduct  field  visits  of  the  pilot  study  area.  The  information  to  be  collected 
includes  the  geological  characteristics  of  the  mine  resource;  current  mining 
operation  and  safety  protection  measures;  history  of  mine  accidents;  and 
estimated amount of methane extraction, potential uses of methane, and markets 
for extracted methane and mine water. 
 
B.  Part II: Review and Analysis of International Experience 
 
4.  During part II, the consultants will do the following: 
(i)  Review international experience with and history of coal mine accidents and 
subsequent  investigation  methodologies,  technology  improvements,  safety 
training, emergency plans, and government regulatory actions and discuss their 
relevance to the PRC in view of the current coal mining methods used and types 
of mine accidents. 
(ii)  Review international codes and standards for mine safety and workers’ health, 
such as US federal code regulations for underground coal mines, 30CFR Part 75, 
administered by the Mine Safety and Health Administration. 
(iii)  Review international experience, policies, and regulations in terms of beneficial 
uses or disposal of water produced from CBM and CMM extraction and flood 
control.  
(iv)  Review international research and development activities in improving the safety 
of coal mining. 
(v)  Review international experience with and the economics of automating mining 
processes, such as long wall mining, to improve mine safety and assess the 
relevance and applicability of automation to the PRC.  
(vi)  Review international experience of the private sector in coal mine safety, such as 
investing in CBM extraction plants and beneficial uses of the water generated by 
methane  extraction  and  flood  control.  This  review  may  include  government 
policies to improve investments’ financial position, cost-recovery mechanisms, 
cost control measures, adjustments to investment programs, and improvements 
in the performance of units affiliated with coal mine companies. 
(vii)  Conduct an international seminar on coal mine safety. The seminar will introduce 
and evaluate international experience in related areas and its relevance in the 
PRC context to be incorporated in the coal mine safety strategy. International 
and national experts will be invited to present papers and participate in the 
discussions. After the seminar, the consultants will prepare a report summarizing 
the discussions and identifying issues relevant in the PRC context. 
(viii)  Conduct a 2-week international field study program to expose selected personnel 
from SAWS, ZMG, and other government agencies involved in policymaking and 
in  implementing  coal  mine  safety  to  the  latest  trends  and  international  best 
practices. (Please refer to para. 13 of the main text for details.)

Appendix 3  11 
 
C.  Part III: Development of Strategies and Impact Assessment 
 
5.  During part III, the consultants will do the following: 
(i)  Analyze and present the economic, financial, environmental, and social impacts 
and costs of implementing acceptable coal mine safety measures based on a 
comparison  of  historical  practices  of  coal  mine  safety  in  the  PRC  and 
international  best  practices.  The  social  impact  analysis  needs  to  specifically 
address the retraining and employment of miners after the coal industry has been 
restructured to reduce the number of small coal mines or to use more automated 
mining  processes.  In  assessing  cost  recovery,  financing  mechanisms, 
affordability, subsidies, and other issues related to tariffs, the consultants should 
refer to Setting User Charges for Public Services: Policies and Practices of the 
Asian Development Bank.1 
(ii)  Develop regulation and incentive mechanisms to promote coal mine safety, such 
as  formulating  required  safety  codes  and  standards  for  mining  design  and 
operations, devising effective procedures to enforce the implementation of safety 
regulations,  restructuring  the  coal  industry  for  improved  effectiveness  in 
achieving safer operations, allowing coal pricing to be adjusted so that coal mine 
companies  can  implement  safety  measures,  and  providing  credits  or  tax 
incentives  for  the  use  of  extracted  CBM  and  CMM  based  on  international 
protection regulation frameworks on coal mine safety, experiences, and lessons 
learned and their relevance to the PRC. 
(iii)  Determine if market instruments are available, such as noncompliance fees and 
deposit refunds, or are being utilized in more advanced economies for preventing 
and  mitigating  coal  mine  accidents.  Assess  the  applicability  of  implementing 
market-based models to promote coal mine safety under conditions in the PRC. 
(iv)  Recommend a coal mine safety strategy and identify responsible implementation 
agencies at various levels. Identify the legal and regulatory changes required to 
implement the coal mine safety strategy. Discuss the strategy’s relevance in the 
context of social economic conditions, energy conservation, and environmental 
protection.  For  this  purpose,  the  measures  proposed  by  the  State  Council 
(footnote 2 in the main report) should be considered and improved on if there are 
gaps, or if comprehensive, the study can focus on steps to institutionalize them 
for effective implementation. 
(v)  Develop a coal mine safety action plan up to 2020. This will include (a) an 
assessment  of  technologies  for  accident  prevention  and  control,  particularly 
drainage technologies, and for improving CBM and CMM utilization, monitoring, 
and control; (b) a strategy for public dissemination of the TA’s findings and 
recommendations,  including  comprehensive  training  courses;  and  (c)  the 
identification and prioritization of candidate coal mine  safety projects for possible 
ADB financing, and based on the recommendation, an evaluation of the pilot 
project. 
(vi)  Consider the following in relation to item (v): (a) introducing internationally proven 
coal mine safety technologies; and (b) cooperating with international research 
agencies to develop applicable coal mine safety technologies. Such technologies 
may include horizontal drilling of CBM wells to increase methane extraction, 
more cost-effective processes for treating CBM, mining equipment modifications 
to improve operational safety and reduce maintenance costs, hazardous area 
signaling and range monitoring devices, mining ground area structure control 
electrical system protection and advanced mine ventilation.

(vii)  Describe  the  rationale  for  selecting  candidate  projects,  including  technical 
considerations,  investment  requirements  and  implementation  schedules,  and 
potential barriers. Recommend a pilot project, in consultation with ZMG, and 
develop a plan in terms of the technologies to be used, potential participants and 
investors, project schedules, proposed staffing and target users or markets for 
the  extracted  methane  and  mine  water.  Assess  how  methane  will  be 
commercially extracted as an economic source of energy that will be distributed 
to households and industries. Prepare an estimate of project expenditures and 
determine the project’s economic and financial viability. 
(viii)  Assess the general economic, financial, social, and environmental benefits of the 
coal mine safety pilot project in accordance with relevant ADB guidelines.2 
(ix)  Identify assistance required to develop comprehensive proposals for coal mine 
safety projects following discussions with government officials and determine 
project scope. Identify critical issues that need to be addressed and steps that 
need to be taken by government agencies to develop the selected coal mine 
safety projects with assistance from ADB. 
(x)  Develop a strategy for public dissemination of the TA’s findings. 
(xi)  Assess resource requirements and institutional arrangements for monitoring the 
TA’s  impact  and  identify  data  collection,  analysis,  and  reporting  skills  and 
management information system skills required to implement the monitoring and 
evaluation system. Identify training requirements, develop a training manual, and 
provide the necessary training on monitoring.

E.  Reports 
 
7.  The consultants will submit the following reports and conduct the following workshops: 
(i)  Inception  report.  The  report  will  be  submitted  within  1  month  of  TA 
commencement.  It  will  summarize  the  initial  findings  and  suggest  changes 
needed, if any, in the TA’s approach, methodology, and time schedule.  
(ii)  Report  on  the  international  seminar  and  report  at  the  end  of  the 
international field visit program. This report will summarize the main issues 
and findings. 
(iii)  Draft final report and workshop. SAWS and ADB will have 1 month to review 
the report. The report will be discussed at a consultation workshop with the main 
stakeholders, the counterpart team, and the steering committee plus key officials 
from other government agencies involved in coal mine safety. ADB staff will 
participate in the consultation workshop. The main objectives of the workshop 
are to (a) present the findings and recommendations of the TA to policymakers 
and stakeholders, (b) facilitate an exchange of ideas and gather comments, (c) 
increase ownership of and commitment to the TA’s recommendations, and (d) 
allow policymakers to discuss feedback from stakeholders. 
(iv)  Final report and final workshop. One month after the consultation workshop, 
the consultants will submit the final report taking into account the comments of 
SAWS and ADB on the draft final report and the discussions held during the 
consultation workshop. The consultants will finalize the report and translate it into 
Chinese. The consultants will organize a final workshop with participation by the 
main stakeholders to disseminate the TA’s findings and recommendations.
